oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maple Dean Farm: view of front porch with ornate trim
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 400 New Herman Rd, Shelbyville, Bedford Co., TN

Black and white photograph of a white farmhouse with a shingle gable roof; angled front view of one wing of the house; two brick chimneys on roof; front porch has an American flag on it and carved wood cornicing and two visible white columns; two chairs and a table visible behind one column

Maple Dean Farm was established in 1819 by Thomas Dean. It began agricultural operations within the first generations of settlement in Bedford Co., established 1807. Thomas Dean was a prominent Democrat in Tennessee politics during the Second Party System. By the time of his death in 1881, he owned 209 acres. His son Peyton Dean inherited the farm and later gave it to sister Elizabeth Dean upon her marriage to teacher Walter Crigler in 1885. The new Victorian farmhouse was constructed in 1886. It passed to Elizabeth's son John Peyton Crigler in 1911. John Peyton spent nearly a decade turning it into a model progressive operation, including the installation of electricity via a generator. In 1948, the farm was acquired by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Crigler. And in 1976, Maple Dean Farm was certified as a Tennessee Century Farm by the Tennessee Department of Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Century farms
Farmhouses
